content: The Act titled "Higher Education Affordability and Equity Act of 2007" expands the deduction for interest on education loans. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal the dollar limitation and increase the phaseout beginning point for the deduction under section 221. The deduction amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with a threshold of $100,000 ($200,000 for joint filers). The paragraph discusses the calculation of the deduction amount based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with specific thresholds for single and joint filers. It also defines modified adjusted gross income and makes a conforming amendment to the Internal Revenue Code. The definition of 'adjusted gross income' is clarified without considering specific sections, and a conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code for adjustments based on cost-of-living. The cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007, is determined by multiplying a specified dollar amount by the adjustment for the calendar year. SEC. 3 makes the deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses permanent by repealing subsection (e) of Section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 addresses education savings accounts. SEC. 4 increases allowable contributions to education savings accounts from $2,000 to $5,000. Reports for these accounts must be filed by June 30 of the following year. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 increases allowable contributions to education savings accounts and defines qualified higher education expenses and eligible educational institutions. It also modifies special rules for teaching and research assistants. The amendments apply to expenses paid after December 31, 2007, for education provided in academic periods starting after that date. Expansion of educational expenses allowed as part of Hope Scholarship Credit.
